instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.A2251: What is A2251? A2251 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3348, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01949..
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
So I have this board here, no liquid damage, the macbook looks like new. I checked some voltages and found out that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is missing. There is no short on this line, resistance is 112kohm.

Some measurments:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12,60V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3,390V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> = 3,355V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 112kohm

<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD_0</SIGNAL> = 2,52V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD_0</SIGNAL> = 0,90V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCQ_ANI_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 1,80V

I have managed to get in DFU mode, but same error message appears like in recovery mode:

The operation couldn’t be completed. (AMRestoreErrorDomain error 75 - Failed to handle message type StatusMsg (Missing data volume)) [AMRestoreErrorDomain – 0x4B (75)]

In my opinion the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is faulty, because it is not producing the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> line. Am I right?

What do you think guys?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
"Missing data volume" sounds more like SSD problem.
Reflash SoC ROM and try again DFU.

Just in case, check diode mode to ground on all big coils; compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
I have flashed a new Rom but result is same. only difference is now, that it starts directly in DFU mode not in recovery mode.

I checked following coils, unfortunately not have a good board, but for some coils the readings are in felxbv:

L8100 = 0,16V should be 0,072V
<SIGNAL>L3500_VWR</SIGNAL> = 0,18V should be 0,511V
L7660 = 0,47V is ok
L7030 = 0,51V is ok
<SIGNAL>L3500_VXT</SIGNAL> = 0,21V
L8410 = 0,9V

L7210 = 0,08V should be 0,331V
L7220 = 0,08V should be 0,330V
L7230 = 0,08V should be 0,330V
L7400 = 0,15V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
CPU core coils have very low resistance to ground as normal; 0.08 should be good there.
You should compare the other coils with good board.

Also check all outputs on page 64.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: I don't know why, but today board stuck at 5V and will not switch to 20V. I swear yesterday it switched to 20V. I will take later some new measurments but for the first, it switches to 20v only if battery is connected. Without battery <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12,61V -> too low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12,29V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3,31V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> = 3,38V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5,06V

<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> = 1ohm
<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> = 1ohm
<RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR> = 1ohm
<RESISTOR>R7062</RESISTOR> = 1ohm

Looks like <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is faulty...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
Why do you think <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is fault?
Did you check <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> = 0,0V / 2,4Mohm / 0,47V

Why do you think <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is fault? Because in the repair wiki manual, it says that is very likely that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is faulty.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
It can't generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> by itself.
It is controlled by SMC through SMBUS.
And SMC got an error from USB-C area; <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> must be high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: ok so any other ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: Can't complete DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: It aborts always with same error

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: I found something very weird. When I connect the charger on the same usb side as the thunderbolt cable to other macbook and the revive the macbook, after some seconds in step 4 of 4 (installing system) the voltage jumps to 20V. In this moment <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> = 1,8V. But it aborts with same error. Now I'm totally confused. I tried this with naked board and also with all cables plugged but same result. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> in this moment is still 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: Battery also connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
The measurments were taken only board nothing connected. With battery connected the charger do instantly 20V. But error is same, doesn't matter if all components are plugged in or not. I found this topic here

[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2251</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-not-turning-on-probably-corrupted-t2.62983/[/URL]

Looks no solution for this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
Error 75 can be caused by faulty CPU.
"Missing data volume" sounds more like SSD problem.

Apple made all possible to confuse us.
There is no interest to repair its boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: I have some update on this board. I found a mess/short under the onboard display connector see pictures. Unsoldered the connector all pins are fine. Because I have not diode values of exact this board I took values from the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board. Pin 1 and 3 are oL. These are connected directly to cpu. So faulty cpu? How can I found out if display is ok? Are there some values for displays?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: If you've measured correctly (red probe on ground), the CPU's eDP output is damaged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message: Yes measurment was correct. What is eDP for? Is a cpu swap a solution for this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in recovery
threads.message:
eDP stands for embedded Display Port.
Is the actual video bus, used in almost all laptops.

As there is no series capacitor for any eDP line, you must change the CPU.
